title: DECLARE (Snowflake Scripting) | Snowflake Documentation
paragraphs: Declares one or more Snowflake Scripting variables, cursors, RESULTSETs, or exceptions.
For more information on variables, cursors, RESULTSETs, and exceptions, see:
Working with variables
Working with cursors
Working with RESULTSETs
Handling exceptions
LET
The syntax for each type of declaration is described below in more detail.
Variable declaration syntax
Cursor declaration syntax
RESULTSET declaration syntax
Exception declaration syntax
Use the following syntax to declare a variable.
Where:
The name of the variable. The name must follow the naming rules for Object identifiers.
A SQL data type.

Assigns the value of expression to the variable. If both type and expression are specified, the
expression must evaluate to a data type that matches, or can be implicitly cast to, the
specified type.
For example:
For a complete example, see Examples.
For more information about variables, see Working with variables.
Use the following syntax to declare a cursor.
Where:

The name to give the cursor. This can be any valid Snowflake identifier
that is not already in use in this block. The identifier is used by other cursor-related commands, such as
FETCH.
The query that defines the result set that the cursor iterates over.
This can be almost any valid SELECT statement.
For example:
For more information about cursors (including complete examples), see Working with cursors.
Use the following syntax to declare a RESULTSET.
Where:
The name to give the RESULTSET.
The name should be unique within the current scope.
The name must follow the naming rules for Object identifiers.
Preview Feature — Open
Available to all accounts.
Runs the query as an anonymous child job.

The query can be any valid SQL statement, including SELECT statements and DML statements, such as INSERT
or UPDATE.

When this keyword is omitted, the stored procedure runs child jobs sequentially, and each child job waits for
the running child job to finish before it starts.

You can use this keyword to run multiple child jobs concurrently, which can improve efficiency and reduce overall
run time.

You can use AWAIT and CANCEL
statements to manage asynchronous child jobs for a RESULTSET.
Assigns the value of query to the RESULTSET.
For example:
For more information about RESULTSETs (including complete examples), see Working with RESULTSETs.
Use the following syntax to declare an exception.
Where:
The name to give to the exception.

A number to uniquely identify the exception. The number must be an integer between -20000 and -20999. The
number should not be used for any other exception that exists at the same time.
Default: -20000

A message to describe the exception.
The message must not contain any double quote characters.
Default: Empty string.
For example:
For more information about exceptions (including complete examples), see Handling exceptions.
